title: Brexit news Irish border EU negotiations Nadine Dorries ITV Peston
story: Nadine Dorries, Conservative MP for Mid Bedfordshire, argued the Irish border issue should stop being &ldquoweaponised by MPs to aggravate the ongoing Brexit negotiations.Speaking on ITV&rsquos Peston on Wednesday, she said: &ldquoThe Irish border question has got to stop being put forward as a red herring.&ldquoThe Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA) produced a paper this week which showed quite clearly that this is being put forward as a red herring, which is being weaponised and is being used to obfuscate and make the negotiations more difficult.In a bold statement, she added: &ldquoThe Irish border issue does not exist.                Oh, Jeremy...he fails to name one of his party&rsquos Brexit tests                Now the US backs the UK over our Brexit decision - EXPRESS COMMENT Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair&rsquos former political advisor, retorted sharply, stating: &ldquoThe Irish border problem is real, and if there was a solution to it we would have found it by now.In a quick rebuke to Ms Dorries and the Brexiteer faction of the Conservative Party, he added: &ldquoIt is mind-blowing that your wing of your party is so cavalier about the genuine impact on the peace process.&ldquoIf you want to wreck the peace process and wreck the UK, that will be on your hands.Ms Dorries rejected Mr Campbell&rsquos statement, and noted she was simply trying to &ldquodeliver on what people voted for in the 2016 EU referendum.Nadine Dorries argued the Irish border issue is being used to 'obfuscate' the Brexit negotiations (Image: ITV)Alastair Campbell described Ms Dorries' comments as 'mind-blowing' (Image: CHRISMCANDREW)Amber Rudd said she would vote down a Canada-style Brexit trade arrangement (Image: ITV)She also pointed to the &lsquomaximum facilitation&rsquo model as a viable solution to the ongoing deadlock surrounding post-Brexit trade between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.She said: &ldquoWe need the modern technology that we have available to monitor and chart traffic and goods going across.&ldquoThere is already a border, there are two currencies, there is trade already happening across the borders, that is the fact. There is already a border, just not a hard border.&ldquoPeople talk about the Irish border rather than talking about a hard border, or the Irish &lsquobackstop&rsquo. We don&rsquot need any of those.                Sky News host OWNS Chakrabarti with key point on Corbyn's speech                BELIEVE IN BREXIT! May and Trump plot GREAT AMERICAN TRADE DEALAmber Rudd warned there is an 'impasse' in Parliament over Brexit (Image: )Mr Campbell shot back, stating: &ldquoThe technologies aren&rsquot available.&ldquoIt is mind-blowing, mind-blowing.The &lsquomaximum facilitation&rsquo option would see the UK implement technology and a &lsquotrusted trader&rsquo plan to reduce post-Brexit customs checks by monitoring goods and vehicles passing across the Irish border.Critics have nevertheless argued the implementation of the system will take too long due to a lack of adequate technology, and warned it could reintroduce a degree of friction at the border, threatening further violence in Northern Ireland.Alastair Campbell warned the technology required to implement to 'max fac' option does not exist (Image: )Ms Dorries also clashed with former Home Secretary Amber Rudd, who argued a Canada-style Brexit trade arrangement would not work if Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposal is rejected.Ms Rudd said: &ldquoI think there are conceivably about 40 of us in the Tory Party who would not support a Canada-style deal.&ldquoTo be frank, there are so many reasons why the Canada-style deal would not work, starting with the Irish border, going onto manufacturing.&ldquoThat just reinforces the point that there is an impasse.Ms Dorries responded defiantly: &ldquoIf you think we are going to fall off a cliff with &lsquono deal&rsquo, then that is something we need to vote for.

title: brexit no deal theresa may chequers EU
story: At least four MPs are said to be backing the Canada arrangement instead of a no-deal, which Theresa May has threatened if the EU does not bend from its hardline stance.Meanwhile former Home Secretary Amber Rudd has upped the stakes by hinting support for a second referendum.A leaked document has offered an insight into the preparations underway aimed at keeping Britain afloat in the absence of a withdrawal agreement, with Mrs May telling a summit of business leaders yesterday she &ldquodidn&rsquot know where negotiations would end up.Ministers are concerned at Mrs May&rsquos vow to take the UK out of the bloc on March 29 without a deal if her Chequers proposals, which European Council President Donald Tusk told last week&rsquos Salzburg summit &ldquowill not work, are rejected once again another summit scheduled for October 18.&nbsp                No deal Brexit STILL better than Brexiteer plan                'THIS is the only thing that can save May' REVEALEDHowever, big hitters including Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and Home Secretary Sajid Javid are said to have grave misgivings about her uncompromising approach.Instead, they would like her to back a Canada-style free trade deal which would enable mostly tariff-free trade in goods with the EU - although more restrictions on the movement of services.One source told The Times: &ldquoWe don&rsquot want a no-deal and lots of people think her tactic means we can get there by accident.&ldquoWe think that a Canada deal is better than no deal.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab and Home Secretary Sajid Javid are thought to want a Canada-style deal (Image: )However, to complicate the situation, no clear solution has yet been floated which would resolve the question of the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, arguably the biggest impediment to securing a workable deal.Speaking on Tuesday, Mrs May said a Canada-type arrangement would mean a hard border and would therefore trigger the EU&rsquos backstop clause, which would keep Northern Ireland within elements of the customs union and single market.This in turn would mean a customs border in the Irish Sea, with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) MPs who prop up Mrs May&rsquos Government likely withdrawing their support as a result.She told reporters: &ldquoFirst of all, I&rsquove always said no deal is better than a bad deal. I think a bad deal will be a deal, for example, that broke up the United Kingdom. We want to maintain the unity of the United Kingdom.                What is a Canada style Brexit deal? What did the IEA proposal say?                May faces internal threat as ERG group vows to bring down Chequers Theresa May appeared to rule the idea out as a bad deal yesterday (Image: )&ldquoWhat we&rsquove put on the table is a good deal. It&rsquos a deal that retains the unity of the United Kingdom, our constitutional integrity.&nbsp&ldquoIt&rsquos a deal which provides for no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland, protects jobs and enables us to have a good trade relationship with Europe and good trade relationships with the rest of the world.She followed this up by telling the Bloomberg Business Summit in New York yesterday: &ldquoWe don&rsquot know when negotiations will end.&ldquoWe have to ensure we&rsquore prepared for any eventuality.&nbspInternational trade secretary Liam Fox is among those advocating a hard Brexit (Image: )&ldquoMy job is to ensure we&rsquove put in place the steps that make sure that if it is that worst-case scenario we will still make a success of it.Mrs May is also faced with a significant number of ministers who favour a hard Brexit, with the Times suggesting Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, Leader of the Commons Andrea Leadsom, the International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt, and Liam Fox, International Development Secretary, are in this camp.An agenda leaked after a private session at which envoys discussed ways of keeping aircraft flying, medicine supplies moving and ports in the event of a no-deal scenario gave an indication of the intensity of the activity going on behind the scenes.It said: &ldquoPreparedness work has to intensify in the months ahead, at national as well as EU level, as uncertainty remains about the outcome of the negotiations and the ratification of a possible deal.Former Home Secretary Amber Rudd has hinted at support for a second referendum (Image: )Ms Rudd said yesterday there were circumstances in which she could be persuaded to back a second vote.She said: &ldquoNo deal is something parliament would object to.&ldquoA people&rsquos vote is something that could result from an impasse. Is it preferable to no deal, absolutely.

title: autumn budget statement october 29 brexit summit chancellor philip hammond
story: Mr Hammond will now deliver the budget on Monday October 29, earlier than usual, as the Government prepares for a crucial Brexit summit in November.Chancellors normally deliver their autumn statements on the budget in November but EU leaders are due to hold a special summit on November 17 and 18 to thrash out the terms of Britain&rsquos exit from the bloc if sufficient progress in negotiations has been made by then.The Chancellor announced the new date on Twitter.He said: &ldquoI&rsquom pleased to announce the Budget will take place on October 29.                Autumn Budget: Hammond could &lsquoease off austerity measures&rsquo&ldquoI&rsquoll set out how our balanced approach is getting debt falling while supporting our vital public services, and how we are building a stronger, more prosperous economy.It is the first time since 1962 the Government has unveiled its set-piece tax and spending plans on a Monday, leaving some observers to question if the traditional Wednesday is being avoided because it is also Halloween.The Treasury said the timing allowed parliament more time to debate the budget measures before the Commons rose for recess on November 6.It said in a statement: &ldquoThis will set out the government&rsquos plan to build a stronger, more prosperous, economy, building on the recent spring statement and last year&rsquos budget.Chancellor Philip Hammond (Image: PA)Theresa May in Salzburg (Image: )European Council President Donald Tusk confirmed the November summit during last week&rsquos tense gathering in Salzburg.He said: &ldquoThe Brexit negotiations are entering their decisive phase. Various scenarios are still possible today but I&rsquod like to stress that some of Prime Minister May&rsquos proposals from Chequers indicated positive evolution in the UK&rsquos approach.&ldquoThere is perhaps more hope but there is surely less and less time.&ldquoEvery day that is left we must use for talks. I&rsquod like to finalise them still this autumn.                Remainer Hammond INFURIATES May by pushing for Brexit DELAY Mrs May has already insisted extending the deadlocked talks beyond November is not an option.Mr Hammond is coming under pressure from within the Conservative Party to ease his grip on public spending to counter the frustration of many voters with nearly a decade of spending cuts to many areas of public services and Theresa May has already promised a big increase in the budget for the NHS.Mr Hammond has prioritised cutting public debt as a share of Britain&rsquos economic output, saying it could prevent the government from countering any future economic downturn with fresh stimulus spending.

And meditation has much to do with that.The Duchess explained the type of meditation has been praised by people such as Russell Simmons and said people claim it &ldquochanges their life and the trajectory of their future - more success, more fulfillment, more happiness, less worry.She was intrigued by the idea and decided to take Light&rsquos course.She added: &ldquoI know you&rsquoll think of a million excuses as to why this is silly or why you don&rsquot have time for it much like the day I told Light I didn&rsquot have enough hours in the day to do it, and he told me that&rsquos why I needed to meditate twice as much.Meghan Markle had her life changed by a  (Image: )Meghan cooking at a charity event (Image: )Meghan included her own 5-step process for those who want to follow in her footsteps.The first step is to get into a comfortable seating position.The second is to set a finish time, but don&rsquot set an alarm as this may shock you out of your meditation.Then you should notice your breathing and when your mind wanders.The fourth step is to just embrace your thoughts. title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn second referendum vote latest Liverpool Labour Party Conference
story: Angry Liverpudlian Neil Barrow tore into activists campaigning for a second Brexit referendum, insisting the word of the people had come out in favour of Leave.Mr Barrow expressed his indignation at the outrageous proposal after the Labour&nbspParty overwhelmingly&nbspvoted in favour of opening up a path to a new referendum if Theresa May fails to deliver a satisfactory deal.He told Express: We&rsquove had the one vote, we voted out. If that is the word of the people, that should be it. That&rsquos an outrage, absolute outrage that is.When everyone voted for it, the people who voted out didn&rsquot expect it to take this long. They just expected it to be done and get on with life normally.                Labour member sparks ROARING APPLAUSE in speech against bloc                Jeremy Corbyn SPEECH: Read the Labour leader's speech in FULL Mr Barrow appeared upbeat about the prospects independence from the European Union holds for the UK, saying that the country will march on whatever happens after March 2019.He continued: It&rsquos not going to be the end of the world because we&rsquore going out. We&rsquoll march on.Asked whether he was concerned about Jeremy Corbyn entering Number 10, he added: Yes, it concerns me.Labour delegates on Tuesday voted in a majority to keep the option of a fresh Brexit vote &ldquoon the table during the party&rsquos annual conference in Liverpool.Brexit news: Mr Barrow said he felt  (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bullBBC)Shadow Brexit secretary Sir&nbspKeir Starmer&nbspsaid the party leadership had not ruled out the possibility of Labour campaigning for the option to remain in the EU to be included in a possible second referendum ballot paper.But shadow chancellor John McDonnell had previously dismissed altogether the possibility of a new vote, arguing that a fresh referendum would &ldquoide the country again.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.That is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Additional reporting by Darren Hunt and Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.&nbsp

title: lily allen calais apology refugee film
story: The 31-year-old broke down in tears as she visited a refugee camp in Calais in 2016, which was filmed as part of the Victoria Derbyshire show on the BBC.In the clip she said: &ldquoI apologise on behalf of my country, I&rsquom sorry for what we&rsquove put you through.She then burst into tears while interviewing a 13-year-old Afghan boy.Following the film, she received a backlash online with one social media user telling her to &ldquoput away the crocodile tears and speak for herself.                Jonathan Ross Show: Lily Allen reveals dad Keith&rsquos anger at drug claim                ITV Loose Women: Lily Allen slammed for &lsquohardly speaking&rsquo in interviewLily has apologised for comment she made during a BBC documentary segment when she visited the Calai (Image: BBC)But in her new memoirs published this month, titled My Thoughts Exactly, she wrote: &ldquoIt was a clumsy thing to say.I wanted to say, &lsquoI&rsquom sorry,&rsquo and I wanted to acknowledge that I was part of the problem, and that we are all part of the problem if we don&rsquot do more to help.&ldquoThe words came out badly, and for that I felt foolish. I was embarrassed about putting it like that.&ldquoI can be a moron. But my intentions were straightforward and without any agenda. I just wanted to help, in whatever tiny way I could.Lily said her heart was in the right place when she made the comments in 2016 (Image: BBC)She also wrote how online bullying had gone &ldquooff the charts following her comments, and revealed how haters even targeted her children.Speaking on Loose Women on Monday, Ms Allen said that she had written the memoirs in order to explain to her children why she had made certain choices when they were small.Allen told the programme: &ldquoA lot of the decisions that I made when my children were really, really small will have a lasting effect on them.&ldquoAnd if I don&rsquot tell them the truth then they will internalise those feelings of neglect or whatever it was and I think that I&rsquod rather that they know that it was mummy&rsquos fault rather than think &lsquoit&rsquos my fault&rsquo.                Lily Allen claims she has NO space for refugees in luxury London flat                Lily Allen near tears as she is 'robbed' of Mercury Prize - VIDEOLily Allen opened up about her new book on Loose Women this week (Image: ITVLOOSEWOMEN)During her visit to the camp, which was dubbed &ldquothe Calais Jungle, Ms Allen asked the Afghan teenager why a teenager left his home country for Europe, to which the boy replies: &ldquoThe Taliban were going to kill me, they were on one side and Daesh were on the other, my father sold land and sent me here.The award-winning singer then tells the teenager he has a &ldquolegal right to be in the UK and asks if he has started the process of applying to enter the UK legally.The boy replies: &ldquoThe legal process is very slow, you wait for at least three or four months. It&rsquos too slow. The way I am trying works better.Allen replied: &ldquoIt just seems that at three different intervals in this young boy&rsquos life, the English have put you in danger.&ldquoWe&rsquove bombed your country, put you in the hands of the Taliban and now putting you at risk, risking your life to get into our country.

title: Brexit news Sky News Shami Chakrabarti Labour Jeremy Corbyn conference speech today latest
story: Labour Attorney General Shami Chakrabarti was put on the spot on Wednesday as she was questioned about her party's strategy for Brexit.Sky News host Mark Austin pressed Ms Chakrabarti to explain how Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn could demand clarity on the British Government's plans on leaving the European Union when his party itself struggled to come up with a common position.Mr Austin said: Jeremy Corbyn saying time is running out &lsquoin the absence of any clarity from the Government,&rsquo is a bit rich, isn&rsquot it?Because where is the clarity from your party? Are we anywhere near knowing what Labour's policy is?                Labour member sparks ROARING APPLAUSE in speech against bloc                Angry Liverpudlian blasts Corbyn over 'OUTRAGEOUS' calls for new voteThe Sky News presenter also took a dig at the six tests Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer insists any deal negotiated with Brussels must pass to be acceptable to Labour.Mr Austin branded the criteria impossible to deliver before questioning Ms Chakrabarti on how plans for a new general election supported by the upper echelons of the Labour Party would benefit the UK.He continued: The truth is these are impossible tests to meet at this stage. Isn&rsquot it clear that your policy seems to be to sabotage any deal, push for a general election? How does that benefit Britain?The Labour Attorney General defended her party, insisting it had adopted a well-defined position enshrined in the infamous six-test.&nbspBrexit news: Mark Austin said it was  (Image: SKY NEWS)Ms Chakrabarti said: We set out our tests for what a good Brexit might look like, honouring the referendum results even though we have Remainers and Leavers among our electorate and our membership.Jeremy was clear again today as Keir Starmer has been that if Theresa May cannot honour those commitments we will vote down her deal in the House of Commons, quite possibly with members of her own side.She also denied Labour is attempting to sabotage Brexit: We can&rsquot sabotage a deal because Mrs May is in the room with our European partners.There's is no reason at all why she can&rsquot step up to the plate and ignore her hard right Brexiteers in her party and make sure we have a decent customs arrangement, we make sure there is no hard border that jeopardises the peace process in Northern Ireland. title: Hurricane Rosa tracker LIVE path NOAA update Mexico major hurricane
story: Hurricane Rosa is tracking alongside the Mexican coast (Image: NOAA)Hurricane Rosa is the tenth hurricane of Pacific hurricane season, which lasts for around six months bringing dangerous storm systems across warm waters.&nbspPacific hurricane season began on May 15 in the eastern Pacific, and on June 1 in the central Pacific. Both with end on November 30.&nbspHurricane Rosa has been growing in strength, with potential to become a major hurricane as it continues on its path today according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).&nbspBelow are the latest live updates and information on the hurricane. All times are in BST.&nbsp                Hurricane Rosa: NOAA warning as tropical storm to become HURRICANE                Hurricane Rosa update: Tropical Storm Rosa to become MAJOR hurricane12.46pm update: Current location of Hurricane RosaRosa is tracking through the ocean close by Mexico, travelling westward.&nbspAs of their latest update, NOAA place Rosa 630 miles west-southwest of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and 485 miles southwest of the southern tip of Baja California, Mexico.&nbspThe hurricane is moving at a speed of 12mph.&nbsp12.06pm update: Hurricane Rosa set to intensify todayNOAA have been tracking all hurricanes and weather systems in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, and have predicted that Rosa is to intensify today.The weather experts have said: Both atmospheric and oceanic conditions are favorable for intensification with the possibility of rapid strengthening within the next 12 to 24 hours.NOAA also noted that Rosa's cloud patterns are a little more impressive with plenty of deep convection and a well-defined cyclonically-curved band south of the center.&nbsp

title: Hurricane Rosa tracker map Rosa to become MAJOR hurricane NOAA NHC update
story: Hurricane Rosa tracker map: Rosa is forecast to become a major hurricane later today (Image: NOAACYCLOCANE)Hurricane Rosa is currently located about 630 miles west-southwest of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and about 485 miles southwest of the southern tip of Baja California.The soon-to-be major hurricane is moving westward at a speed of 12mph.Maximum sustained winds are near 85mph making Rosa a Category 1 hurricane but the weather system is expected to strengthen today with 111mph winds or higher.When Hurricane Rosa reaches these wind levels, it will be classified as a Category 3 major hurricane on the Saffir-Simpsons Hurricane Wind Scale and can cause devastating damage if it makes landfall. title: northern rail strikes august september routes
story: As Northern insists it is trying to modernise its services, union members have planned to extend walk-outs into October. Heres what we know...Members of the RMT union began the first of many 24 hour strikes on August 25, and again on September 1, 8, 15 and September 22.Northern Rail has confirmed RMT trade union members will also strike on September 29 as well as October 6, 13 and 20.Northern said it would operate about 30 per cent of its usual services.The operator has listed routes which will be affected on its website.Or keep up to date via social media on Twitter @northernassist or FacebookVery few of its trains will run before 9am and after 6pm, a spokesperson warned.Northern advises that Sunday will also see planned cancellations on a small minority of routes, primarily in the north west, and customers should check up to the last minute before travelling.Northern issued a response to RMTs announcement of three further days of strike action on consecutive Saturdays on 6, 13 and 20 October.Richard Allan, Deputy Managing Director, Northern, said: “Northern invited RMT to ACAS talks and agreed to discuss the three options RMT had suggested beforehand on the role of the on-board member of staff.  Northern was prepared to talk about the RMTs options.However, RMT unilaterally changed the basis of what they were prepared to talk about.This is despite the fact that they have reached agreements on similar terms elsewhere in the industry.RMT then called yet more strike action which will only cause further unnecessary dficulty for customers.Northern remains ready to talk about the options and calls on RMT to cancel strike action and  to the talks.Northern is getting on with the important job of modernising local rail for customers with new trains, better stations and more services.It remains willing to involve RMT in that positive future for colleagues and customers. But progress can only be achieved through talking.Walkouts have also occurred on other operators such as Southern, Merseyrail, Greater Anglia and South Western Railway over the year.Rail union RMT has accused Northern of refusing point blank to engage in serious and meaningful talks.But the union claimed driver-only operation was being extended in the name of increased profits.In a statement, Northern said: We maintain that talking costs nothing, whilst strike action causes inconvenience to customers and damages the case for long-term investment in rail.In previous strikes, Northern said almost 1,400 trains would run on each day of industrial action — around half the usual number.Mick Cash, RMT general secretary, said: Members have been in dispute for well over a year now in a battle to put public safety before private profit and we are angry and frustrated that a genuine opportunity to reach an agreement has been kicked back by the company.Northern Rail want to run nearly half a million trains a year without a safety critical guard on board in a move that would wreck both safety and access ‎to services.

title: autumn begin summer end autumnal equinox
story: Heres when the seasons officially change in 2018.There are two dferent dates that mark the end of summer and the beginning of autumn.These depend  you are referring to astronomical autumn or the meteorological autumn.For meteorologists, summer came to an end on August 31 and autumn began on September 1, running until Thursday, November 30.But astronomers say summer ended on September 22 in the northern hemisphere and autumn began on Friday, September 23.Both astronomers and meteorologists use dferent ways in deciding when the seasons change.For meteorologists, they use the Gregorian calendar to split the year into four equal periods to help them with weather forecasting.This means they define autumn as taking place in September, October and November - so for them, autumn began on September 1 and runs until November 30.But astronomers base their seasons on celestial events, and for autumn, the date is decided when the hours of daylight and darkness are roughly the same, known as the equinox.This usually occurs around September 21-24 in the northern hemisphere, and astronomers believe the first day of autumn lies within this region.There is also a third way of determining when autumn starts that is used by people who study phenology - plant and animal le cycles.They look to changes in the natural world to determine seasons changing such as leaves changing colours and autumn fruits ripening.But this relies more on weather, so the date for this can be open and change vastly each year.This year the autumn equinox in the northern hemisphere took place on September 23 - the same day as the beginning of astronomical autumn.The autumn equinox marks the day when the northern hemisphere slightly tilts away from the sun, meaning days become shorter and the temperature begins to cool.It is the day when daylight hours and night-times is of equal .This carries on until the winter solstice when the northern hemisphere begins to tip back towards the sun on its axis.The end of autumn officially falls on December 21.

title: jezza may snap election brexit
story: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is so desperate for a fresh election he will swallow his lelong hatred of the EU and support a second referendum.And Tory PM Theresa May would rather call a snap ­election than have another Brexit poll.So, despite Downing Street denials, it looks as  we are lurching towards a showdown which risks 1,000 years of British democracy.For be in no doubt, a Corbyn election victory and a Marxist-led Momentum regime would fundamentally change our way of le, our economy and the social fabric of this nation.Even a coalition with other parties would hand Momentum anarchists control over crucial levers of power.This week’s Labour conference in Liverpool is a Jezza rally, with far-left cheerleaders clamouring to bring down the Tories.Almost 90 per cent want a second referendum. Until now, Jezza — a staunch Bennite eurosceptic — has resisted any move to overturn Brexit. Yesterday, in a remarkable U-turn, he vowed to accept whatever delegates say.So abject surrender to the mob is the price he will pay to destroy Theresa May. “I enjoy being leader,” he said yesterday. “I am carrying on as leader of the Labour Party because I want to win an election.”His persistence in the face of scathing personal ratings is the only glint of sunlight for stricken Tories.Under any other leader, even snooty wannabe Emily Thornberry, Labour would be miles ahead.But we have learned not to underestimate Corbyn.The People’s Vote movement probably has the numbers in Parliament to vote down any deal Mrs May brings back from Brussels.These so-called “moderates”, including the slippery Peter Mandelson, leadership flop David Miliband and decrepit Vince Cable, should be careful what they wish for.In normal times, the Tories would beat off the Momentum marauders. But for all her brave talk in Downing Street last week, Mrs May is a real political liability.She destroyed both her credibility and her majority in last year’s unforced contest.The public mood on Brexit is volatile and unpredictable.Most people believe the majority for Brexit, fuelled by EU arrogance and plain bad manners, could actually grow. But nobody’s sure.A snap election would focus the public’s attention on the choice between a clean break and a botched compromise which will never be acceptable to all sides.It could cauterise the issue which still ides families and friends. Or it could backfire badly.Tory Brexiteers must think hard before pulling the plug on the Maybot. It could split their party asunder.But so could Jeremy Corbyn’s rank opportunism.Blairite Labour moderates must soon choose.If they help Jeremy Corbyn win a vote of no confidence, what do they do next?Will they campaign for a party whose rampant extremists wish them dead? Will they stay silent while Momentum activists unseat their moderate comrades?Can deputy Tom Watson support a leader whose own MPs need round-the-clock armed guards against his dangerously fanatical supporters?Can they ignore threats of rape and torture? Nothing is too extreme or too petty for these thugs. They even want ex-Labour luvvie Maureen Lipman sacked from Corrie for attacking their Beloved Leader.Anyone who thinks images of Marxist anarchy are far-fetched should listen to Corbyn sidekick Dawn Butler praising the 1980s Militant Tendency — the forerunner to Momentum — which almost bankrupted Merseyside.“We are in Liverpool where over 30 years ago the council stood up to Thatcher and said, better to break the law than break the poor,” she ranted.That was when Labour split asunder for the first time, creating a new Social Democrat party which posed a short-lived threat the Tories.Roy Hattersley, deputy leader in those turbulent times, warns the party could split again today. “All we need is for one of the hard-working, long-suffering MPs to be kicked out and the whole thing will blow up in our faces,” he said yesterday.The Tories just need to be patient.Albanian drug gangs are gaining market share from Bulgarians, Romanians and Colombians by slashing cocaine prices.Police arrested a record 4,000 peddlers operating across county lines, mostly too young to charge.Kne crime among Somalis, Eritreans and Nigerians is soaring.Meanwhile, there’s a growth spurt in modern slavery.Organised crime is a multi-billion-pound industry affecting “more UK citizens, more often, than any other national security threat,” says the National Crime Agency.All despite Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Rumours of a snap election in November, just four months before we leave the EU, are deeply concerning.Not only does it give the impression of a Government in chaos, it would cost Britain valuable negotiating time.Decision time is quickly approaching for Theresa May.“Brexit means Brexit” will soon need flesh added to the bones: the Chequers compromise or the more ambitious — but more dficult to deliver — model presented by free traders today.And far from pondering her domestic strength, she should focus on flexing her muscles with Brussels.Above all, it means reminding that unconvincing Napoleon tribute act Emmanuel Macron and the tight-fisted Angela Merkel that we’re perfectly happy to break free without paying a penny of our £39billion “exit deal”.They must know that asking their own increasingly Eurosceptic voters to fill the hole left by our departure could bring down the whole house of cards.And keeping that cash here would pay for plenty of tax cuts, making the UK even more competitive on a global stage.It’s time to get tough. title: indian summer name uk weather latest
story: Heres what you need to know about the Indian Summer which could see the country basking in temperatures hotter than Greece.An Indian Summer means a period of unseasonably warm, dry and calm weather which can make for an Autumnal heatwave.According to the BBC, highs of 27-29C have happened before in late September.The mercury has soared to 30C on several occasions during the last week of the month, while the highest October temperature ever recorded in the UK was 29.4C in the small market town of March, Cambridgeshire, on the first day of the month in 1985.An Indian Summer is usually followed by a period of colder weather or frost in the late Autumn.The term Indian summer reached England in the 19th century, during the heyday of the British Raj in India leading to the belief that the term referred to the Indian subcontinent.However its claimed the term was first coined by the Native Americans, and it was used there in the late 18th century.The first reported use of the word was recorded in Letters from an American Farmer in 1778 by American soldier turned farmer J. H. St. John de Crèvecoeur.Then a severe frost succeeds which prepares it to receive the voluminous coat of snow which is soon to follow though it is often preceded by a short interval of smoke and mildness, called the Indian Summer, he wrote.The term then often appeared in American literature across the following century and, according to Phrases.org, in the 1830s, Indian Summer was used figuratively to refer to any late flowering following a period of decline. Following Storms Ali and Bronagh, the weather looks set to do a U-turn in the last week of September with temperatures beginning to climb to 23C by Thursday September 27 - making it hotter than Athens.The south, Wales and the Midlands will see the best of the weather with glorious sunshine as Brits enjoy an Indian Summer.But the north will see more wind and outbreaks of rain through the week and cloudier skies - although temperatures will still be warmer than the recent chillier conditions.And sunshine is predicted for most the UK at the weekend.The Met Office said: A north-south split will develop through the middle of the week, becoming cloudier and windy with some rain in the North. but remaining settled, dry and mostly sunny in the South.Through the rest of September the weather should stay largely settled with long spells of sunshine and generally light winds.For October, settled and drier conditions are likely to dominate across many parts of the UK during the beginning of this period.

title: jane moore katie price rehab romance
story: The second time was in January 2016, behind the scenes of Loose Women.In the intervening years, I had made several waspish remarks about her on this very page  so fully expected a frosty exchange.But she was disarmingly self-deprecating, funny and, to my utter surprise, very much a woman’s woman.“I know you think I’m a nightmare,” she said matter-of-factly. “And you’re probably right. But I think we’re going to get on.”She was right. We did. The other panellists liked her too.Predominantly mothers, we treated her as one might a naughty niece you were particularly fond of, rolling our eyes and smiling affectionately as she regaled us with the latest relationship drama in her le.But despite her no-nonsense, often humorous delivery, there was always a faint “here we go again” sadness behind her eyes and, as I saw it, a low self-esteem that might explain the constant cosmetic alterations and propensity to criticise herself before anyone else could.After reading the recent headlines of wild nights out and rap songs about cocaine, it’s easy to think that Katie is a party girl who has largely abandoned her children as an inconvenience to the carefree lestyle she longs to have.And, judging by yesterday’s letters page, plenty of you do.Before getting to know her, I might have shared that view. But now I see her admittedly destructive behaviour as a cry for help and I’m relieved that, finally, she’s in to rehab to get it.Once, in a rare flash of what I feel is the real Katie, she told me that her Holy Grail was to find a decent, dependable man who could pay the bills while she stayed home and ran a large, chaotic farmhouse full of children and animals.Her favourite night of the week was Friday, when she would wipe off her “work face”, slip in to her old trackie bottoms and call in a takeaway for her, her now estranged third husband Kieran and the kids.Anyone who has seen her interacting with Harvey, her severely disabled eldest son, will know that she’s a fundamentally devoted mother doing her best  in often trying circumstances.Remember her in the I’m A Celebrity jungle? Free of make-up, her hair in braids, tackling each challenge with an admirably no-nonsense bravado? To my mind, that’s the real Katie — the rest is just noise.But without doubt, she has a self-destructive streak when she feels let down.So, after catching Kieran having an affair with her “best friend”, forgiving him, then catching him again with someone else, it was inevitable that a fall was coming. Her mum Amy said at the weekend: “Kate has been her own worst enemy and behaved like an idiot at times but she has been tearing herself apart for years.“All the men in her le have used Katie, and never, ever leave her alone . . . Kieran almost destroyed Kate with his behaviour, Alex  has been as bad, and Pete  likes to portray himself as perfect . . . they all know that  they wind her up, she will react.“Kate is stupid for reacting, but these men need to look at how they are behaving and take some responsibility.”Wise words. And Katie needs to heed them as much as her former husbands.She’s always been disarmingly frank about the incidents in her le that would have sent many of us over the edge — not least being sexually abused when she was just six years old. But now it’s time for her to stop shrugging them off as “just one of those things” and take a long, hard look at how they’ve shaped her often destructive behaviour patterns as an adult.I hope she sticks with the therapy and, ultimately, finds contentment.HOT on the stilettos of Stormy Daniels’ lurid description of Donald Trump’s manhood, singer Cher has been regaling us with tales of her former lovers.Tom Cruise is in her “top five” but legendary lothario Warren Beatty was, apparently, a disappointment.Cher, 72, explains: “Not that he wasn’t technically good, but I didn’t feel anything.”We remain blissfully unaware of whether she means emotionally or physically.EAGLE-EYED travellers boarding a flight operated by Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacic noticed this glaring spelling error on the side of the plane.Though it grieves me greatly, spelling errors or “typos” are now commonplace in everyday exchanges via text, tweet or email, but it never ceases to amaze me when they’re writ large on something as expensive as a sign, billboard or, er, Boeing 747.Does no one check these things before literally advertising their ignorance? Seems not.And so, we are entertained by such gems as Shoplters Will Be Prostituted, Chris Is Risen, All Busniesses Open As Usual, Pay and Display Apples In This Area, Costumers Only, Parrallel Parking, No Trough Road and Pedestrain Crossing, to name but a few.And don’t even get me started on missing or misplaced apostraffy’s…WHEN cookery presenter Nadiya Hussain was picked to bake the Queen’s birthday cake in 2016, she recalls feeling that it was an opportunity to act against Islamophobia.“Everybody thinks it, ‘Oh God, who let the Muslim woman near the Queen with a kne?’” she says now. “Let’s address that elephant in the room, because they did.”Nope. Actually, I remember thinking, “Oh, it’s that lovely woman who won Bake Off and made Mary Berry cry tears of joy”.Sorry to disappoint, Nadiya.Quite right too.Particularly as the majority of them are now more recognisable than the “celebrities” they’re dancing with.HOLLYWOOD director Sam Mendes says his now defunct marriage to Kate Winslet struggled because he “was not very comfortable being married to a celebrity . . . it made me feel self-conscious”.Couldn’t he have worked that out before they trotted down the aisle?VIDEO game designers are working on giving avatars real-le emotions to make the experience more authentic.Will they include a frustrated parent yelling: “Get off that bloody thing before you turn in to someone with the physical and people skills of an atrophied three-toed sloth?No, thought not.ACTRESS Helena Bonham Carter says she used a psychic to contact Princess Margaret so she could perfect her role as the Queen’s sister in the forthcoming third series of The Crown.She claims Margaret told her she’s “doing a great job”.Hmmm. From what little one knows of the feisty royal, “fack orf” seems more likely.FRANK SPRINGETT is 91, his we Mary is 86 and they have been married for 67 years.Frank is deaf and suffers from arthritis, Mary has severe Alzheimer’s, and both are being looked after in the same Warwickshire-based care home using funds from the sale of their house.However, the money is now running low and while social services will continue to partially pay for Mary’s care, it says former factory worker Frank has to look after himself.Meaning that 70 years after they met, they face being separated for the first time.“We fear  they are torn apart, the strain will kill them,” says their daughter Joanne, 57.With seemingly endless funds being readily shelled out to help accommodate those  who seek asylum in Britain, how sad that someone who has paid in to the system all their le gets so let down when they need it most.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels eu press regulation sun
story: Justice commissioner Vera Jourova was riled by our front page labelling EU leaders “dirty rats” over their tactics.She accused the UK media of spreading “disinformation” and suggested “smart regulation”.Speaking in Austria, Ms Jourova said: “Media can build the culture of dialogue or sow isions, spread disinformation and encourage exclusion.“The Brexit debate is the best example of that. Do you remember the front page of a popular British daily calling the judges the ‘enemy of the people’?Or just last week, the EU leaders were called ‘dirty rats’ on another front page.Almost daily we could find examples of stories that are spiced up to point out the enemy, to paint the picture black and white.I would advocate for a European approach to media based on quality and smart regulation,  needed.But Tory MEP Amjad Bashir said: “Commissioners should not be trying to shackle the Press.“We politicians do not always like what journalists write, but they have to be free to report the news as they see it.The vibrancy and iety of our newspapers is one of the things that makes Britain great.People have to learn to take the rough with the smooth.Otherwise we are on a slippery slope to state control and oppression.Mr Bashir’s colleague Ashley Fox added: “A free and unfettered media is vital.” EU officials insisted there was no new legislative action in the pipeline in terms of media regulation and that Ms Jourova had been talking about broadcasters.A Commission spokeswoman said she was merely trying to “trigger a discussion”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: happiest places to live britain life satisfaction
story: Brits have been asked to rate their well-being and le satisfaction, with some parts of the country producing happier residents than others.The Office for National Statistics  has upgraded its regular survey of well being by asking residents four questions to determine  they are happy.People were quizzed on how satisfied they are are with their le, to what extent they feel the things they do in their le are worthwhile, how happy they felt yesterday and how anxious they felt yesterday?To answer, those in the survey had to give a personal score out of 10.Overall the UK scored 7.7 out of 10 for le satisfaction, 7.9 out of 10 for feeling worthwhile, 7.5 out of 10 for happiness yesterday and 2.9 out of 10 for feeling anxious yesterday.Rushmoor in Hampshire came out as the happiest place to live, with the people living there scoring it 8.34 out of 10.Whereas those living in Fenland in Cambridgeshire are less enthusiastic about their le there, scoring their happiness level at 6.7 out of 10.Copeland in Cumbria is second ranked in the happiest places in the UK, with a score of 8.24 out of 10.But exclusive Kensington and Chelsea, one of the UKs wealthiest areas, scored low and came in as the second unhappiest place to live.Northern Ireland saw the highest average le satisfaction and happiness ratings when compared with Wales, Scotland and England.And people in London reported a lower average sense that things they do in le are worthwhile.It was also found women reported a higher level of anxiety than man.Silvia Manclossi, Head of Quality of Le Team, Office for National Statistics said: “An important part of our work is looking beyond the economic health of the country to how its people are faring and inequalities in society.Today, for the first time, we have identied how factors such as health, access to services, and crime levels may affect how people rate their well-being in dferent parts of the UK.This can help local authorities and other organisations to better understand where services could be targeted to help improve the well-being of people in their area.”He said earlier in the year: There is a growing recognition that how we are doing as a nation is at least as much about people’s well-being as it is about the country’s economic health.Today’s analysis shows the strengths and challenges of dferent age groups in society.These insights can help target services where they are most needed and can have the best impact.

title: forget everything on a night out how to stop a booze blackout before it happens
story: Apart from it being a pretty terrying experience leaving you consumed with fear the next day, blacking out in a booze-induced stupor can have an alarming effect on the body.Blackouts are a gap in the tape of your memory, said George Koob, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.He told HuffPo that in a blackout, alcohol shuts down the ability of the brain to consolidate memories.Well, it doesnt mean that someone becomes unconscious.As anyone whos humiliated themselves on a night out might know, people tend to continue interacting with other people and engaging in potentially embarrassing or dangerous activities even after their brains have buzzed off.Of course, you can pass out during a blackout - and thats the most dangerous thing about them, with the possibility of sustaining a head injury from falling, choking on vomit or getting alcohol poisoning.But  your mates still compus mentus, then it can be tricky to tell whether theyre approaching blackout mode or not.Theres no definitive guide to blacking out - symptoms can dfer from person to person, or session by session.But common signs that someones very drunk include poor coordination, vomiting or needing help to get home.However there are some signs to watch out for, including:Source: American Addiction Centres“Slurred speech is also common, and people are sensitive to that it’s why police use it as a test,” explained Koob.“Also, same with motor coordination. They might be bumping into things. It’s hard to walk in a straight line when you’re that intoxicated.”A change in personality is also a pretty good indicator, Koob said.One marker I use is dramatic and rapid swings in emotionality.“One moment, your friend might be praising you and telling you how much they care. The next, they turn, and it’s the complete opposite emotion, like anger directed at you.”Its an obvious answer but the key is to drink in moderation - both to protect your dignity and your long-term health.According to Alcohol Concern, excessive drinking is the biggest risk factor for death, ill-health and disability among 15-49 year-olds in the UK - and is the fth biggest factor among all ages.To reduce your chances of developing a whole host of potentially fatal diseases, Public Health England is encouraging middle-aged drinkers to have at least two days a week off the booze.A study from the University of Calornia, San Diego, claimed to have found that around 40 per cent of brains are more prone to blackouts from booze and drugs than others.Well, its all to do with ethanol - a compound found in alcohol.Drinking up to four boozy drinks in a short space of time can heighten its effects - particularly  youve not eaten much.When the stomach is empty, ethanol reaches the blood as soon as half an hour after consumption.That means that as you drink, your blood ethanol level inches high and higher for up to 90 minutes - possibly without realising just how drunk you are until youre already pretty far gone.After a couple of hours on the sauce, that ethanol then dfuses from the blood into the brain.The booze then targets receptors in the part of the brain which controls emotions and recollection, including something called the gamma-aminobutyric acid, or GABA.When GABA receptors are affected by alcohol, the brain stops transmitting signals that would otherwise solidy memories.It also helps the brain to start producing things like dopamine and serotonin, as well as glutamate - the neurotransmitter that results in your feeling calmer.Thats why you often feel amazing when youre drinking...so you drink more - all the while getting increasingly leathered.But that can also lead to you doing things which are out of character. As your inhibitions go down with that fth G&ampT, you start to think that dancing on the tables a good idea, that sexting your boss is totally legit.And the next day, you cant understand why your boss is looking at you oddly from across the office, or why youre covered in bruises from falling off the table.Its not just the damage to your ego thats the problem - blacking out means that youre drinking to excess, and that comes with all the usual health issues associated with drinking, including developing liver problems, heart disease and ious cancers.

title: jeremy corbyn speech labour party conference 2018
story: The hard left leader used his conference speech to party faithful to try to persuade Britain that he is now ready to lead the nation.The 69 year-old doubled down on his Socialist agenda by branding a series of new radical policies “the new political mainstream”.And the party boss claimed that next year’s annual party gathering in September 2019 would meet “as a Labour government”.Mr Corbyn, 69, told the audience in Liverpool that his left wing mass movement in now “ready to take charge”.And he instructed them: “We must take our message to every town, city and village. United and ready to win, ready to govern as we were in 1945, 1964 and 1997.“Let every constituency, every community know Labour is ready.”But at the same time, he also issued an appeal to his bitterly ided party’s Labour’s squabbling factions to unite.Calling on warring MPs and members to “focus on what unites us”, he pleaded: “We need to foster a much greater culture of tolerance. An end to abuse, online and in person.“We must learn to listen a bit more, and shout a lot less.”Mr Corbyn also admitted the summer had been “tough”, after he was repeatedly rocked by an MPs’ revolt over accusations that he held anti-Semitic views.But while admitting that the row “caused immense hurt and anxiety in the Jewish community”, the Labour boss refused to use his major platform to offer Jews another apology.Instead, he only added: “I hope we can work together to draw a line under it”.Mr Corbyn highlighted a series of new policy announcements made through out the four day gathering on Merseyside that have driven Labour even further to the left.They included forcing companies to hand over 10% of their worth to employees, and workers’ takeover of board rooms.He poured fresh scorn on bankers for “piling up profits around the world”.And when the Labour scornfully mentioned Theresa May’s bid to ensire the UK has the lowest corporation tax rates of all the G20 nations, the enterprise-boosting offer was booed by the packed hall.The Labour boss also issued his regular Trump-style rant at the media.JEREMY Corbyn’s speech today drew derision from the Tories - who said his plans would drown Britain in debt and risk betraying Brexit.And Jewish groups criticised the Labour leader for not explaining how he will tackle anti-Semitism. Conservative chairman Brandon Lewis said: Jeremy Corbyn has shown at every turn he is unfit to govern. All he offers are failed ideas that didnt work in the past and would leave working families paying the price with higher taxes, more debt and more waste - just like last time.He confirmed Labour are opening the door to re-running the referendum, which would take us all back to square one.And he didnt even apologise to Jewish people for his total failure to tackle the anti-Jewish racism that is re in the Labour Party.Marie van der Zyl, president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, added: “Jeremy Corbyn’s words mean nothing until Labour takes the necessary steps to deal with anti-Semitism in its ranks.“Words have long ceased to be enough. Actions are what matter.”Unions cheered his proposals for greater state control of industry - but business groups expressed caution.The director general of the CBI, Carolyn Fairbairn, warned that policy built on ideology and diktat would harm those who can least afford it by driving down investment, productivity and pay.Federation of Small Businesses chairman Mike Cherry said: While weve heard some welcome commitments from the Labour Party in the past few days, it should more readily acknowledge the social contribution of businesses across the UK.And free-market think-tanks were also critical - Mark Littlewood of the IEA said: “Jeremy Corbyn is right to highlight that parts of the establishment have far too much control over Britain’s economy.“Westminster’s elite should not be picking winners and losers in business, or deciding whose jobs have guaranteed funding from the taxpayer.“Yet his proposals today – including the creation of 400,000 green energy jobs and increased centralisation of the National Health Service - imagine a Britain in which consumer choice is further limited, and more services are controlled by a select few in Whitehall.” John O’Connell of the Taxpayers’ Alliance added: Corbyns angry rant offered nothing to the hard-pressed, silent majority of taxpayers who want to be trusted to spend their own money and care for their children as they see fit - without being clobbered by even more cruel punishment taxes.” While pledging to protect press freedom, the then immediately insisted: “Freedom here too often means the freedom to spread lies and half truths and to smear the powerless, not take on the powerful”.And he heaped praise in Spanish on his Mexican-born we Laura Alez, telling her from the podium: “Tu eres mi fuerza y mi apoyo. Gracias Laurita ”.Business leaders reacted with horror, with the BCC saying his leftwing package would inflict “a serious impact on business confidence, investment and growth, which ultimately would hurt the very people and communities that need support the most”.Its Director General Adam Marshall added: “While there were some bright spots, Jeremy Corbyn missed a golden opportunity to extend an olive branch to British business, big and small alike”.But unions firebrands loved Mr Corbyn’s 70 minute-long diarribe. Unite general secretary ‘Red Len’ McCluskey dubbed it “*inspiring”.PCS general secretary Mark Serwotka added: Today Jeremy has set out a transformative and radical socialist vision for the country”.Veteran leftwing Labour MP Dennis Skinner was left jubilant, telling the hall: “I want to nationalise something every week”.Tory chairman Brandon Lewis said Mr Corbyn had showed that “at every turn he is unfit to govern”.It was his traditional blend of bile, fantasy and lies, falteringly recited in his two stock voices — all hammily-acted phoney compassion one moment, ­sudden exaggerated rage the next.He turned his ire first on Tories, then on a critical Press. This, he insisted, would remain free under Labour — but not just to print what it liked. Thick as he is, ­Corbyn sees no contradiction.Then it was on to Jezza curing all our ills with freebies galore and mass job creation, all presumably funded by the same tax on the rich. Since Labour aides now privately admit their 2017 manesto secretly covered up a £1TRILLION bill, Corbyn’s assurances aren’t worth the autocue they are written on.This smug, cocky Labour conference is an annual reminder of just what a dishonest rabble they now are. Sickeningly posing as defenders of the dispossessed while plotting to annul their Brexit votes with a second referendum, brought about by orchestrating chaos.One moronic MP even demanded a General Strike to oust the Government. Frontbencher Richard Burgon stood and applauded. And he is the “next Secretary of State for Justice”, God help us.Corbyn is keen to rebrand his extremism as mainstream in an era when capitalism has “failed”. It is, in reality, a dog-eared hard-left roadmap to ruin on a scale we have never experienced. A Britain which would kill ambition and enterprise and drive out successful firms by stealing their property. Where investors would fear to tread and from which anyone who could would flee.Labour’s candidate for PM is a dim, vain, vindictive, unapologetically anti­Semitic ball of rage who loathes scrutiny, lies habitually about his true beliefs and past terrorist connections and is, his aides admit, “not good in the mornings”.But the Tories must not mistake all that for a free pass. Corbyn’s plans have traction only because the Government has left the battlefield. Theresa May and Philip Hammond are timid tinkerers when we need radical steps to put more money in pockets and make homes affordable. Socialism is the last thing we need.Next to last are Tory “Corbyn-lite” tax rises. Record job figures, low inflation and interest rates add up to a society and economy far healthier than the dystopia of chippy Corbynite imaginations.But  the Tories don’t fix the problems that DO exist they’re sunk, and Britain too.Mr Lewis added: “All he offers are failed ideas that didn’t work in the past and would leave working families paying the price with higher taxes, more debt and more waste – just like last time.“He didn’t even apologise to Jewish people for his total failure to tackle the anti-Jewish racism that is re in the Labour Party.”

title: traveller 21 sprayed with ammonia and had hand sliced off with machete after he was lured to meet two teen girls in feud over his sister
story: Ellie Elston, 18, and another girl aged 17 allegedly tricked Francis Doherty, 21, to meet them in West London - where Elstons boyfriend Miles Connors, 23, carried out the violent attack.Connors sprayed his former friend Mr Doherty with the corrosive substance before hacking his hand off and leaving it on the ground, Isleworth Crown Court heard.Police bodycam footage of the aftermath of the attack showed Mr Doherty screaming: “My whole hand’s on the floor. I’m dying, I’m dying”.The jury were told Connors, his brother Daniel, 19, and the two girls kidnapped Mr Dohertys 14-year-old nephew and made him call his uncle as part of the plot.Prosecutor Roger Smart said the boy was stripped naked, wiped down with bleach, dressed in girls’ clothing and told to leave London after the attack.The Evening Standard reported Mr Smart as saying: “[The boy] was told to call Francis Doherty and say that he had met two girls who are interested in meeting him.“Both [the 17-year-old] and Ellie Elston took turns speaking to Francis, enticing him to come and meet them.“They told Francis to attend alone and to look out for a white BMW.Francis agreed to join them and hurriedly made his way to the location.”The court was told Mr Dohertys and Connors families had been at war for some time after Connors made disrespectful remarks about Francis sister, Biddy Doherty.The pair had tried to sort out the problems by fighting in front of a crowd, which Mr Doherty is said to have won.But three days later Connors and his fellow defendants allegedly acted out their bloody revenge plot.With his arm mangled and fearing for his le, Mr Doherty ran behind some parked cars and saw Connors get into a Jeep style vehicle, the prosecution said.In it Mr Doherty saw his nephew, Michael Connors, staring back at him before the vehicle sped off, the jury heard.The kidnap victim was driven around in the boot of a car for four hours before he was released and told not to contact family members or the police, the court heard.Surgeons attempted to reattach Mr Dohertys hand to his arm after the attack in Northolt, West London.Three weeks after the incident Mary Connor, the sister-in-law of Francis Doherty, was allegedly called by members of the Connors family telling them to drop the case for £50,000.If they did not accept, they threatened to kill her and her family, the court was told.Connors, of no fixed address, Daniel Connors, of Northolt, Elston, from North West London, and the 17-year-old girl deny conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to kidnap, conspiracy to falsely imprison, and conspiracy to wound with intent.Connors also denies attempted murder and causing wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm.The Connors sister Christina, 18, and her boyfriend Aidan Mason, 20, are accused of offering £50,000 in cash  Mr Doherty refused to co-operate with police.Mason, from Tottenham, and Christina Connors, from north-west London, both deny perverting the course of justice.The trial continues.

title: moonpig begs customers to stop uploading pics of their genitals to cards in hilarious tweet
story: The custom cards company had people creasing up with its saucy announcement through its official UK Twitter account this morning.It said: Please stop uploading pics of your genitals to our cards it is against our ts and cs.Moonpigs online photo editor allows customers to put their own snaps on greeting cards, as well as other gts including phone cases, t-shirts and mugs.But it seems theyve had enough of seeing some peoples private sentiments being pasted on their presents.The companys content rules strictly prohibit any material that is pornographic, obscene, indecent or offensive being printed on their personalised cards and goods.Clearly some people didnt read the small print.A Moonpig spokesperson told The Sun Online: We’ll produce anywhere between 100-200k cards a day and at least two or three of those might infringe our terms.We have one guy who’s particularly good at spotting them although a couple occasionally slip through the cracks.We also see a massive rise around Valentines Day, with as many as 20 a day that we have to deny.And yes, the girls are as bad as the boys.Followers of the online card company came out with some hilarious responses to the rude revelation.Rachel Hawkins said: My Dad is very apologetic but hes going through a bad time.No excuse I know.Moonpig was in a forgiving mood and replied As long as hes aware now.Scott Bond asked the company: Do you do pop-up cards? Asking for friend.And even more worrying was @Sharron_Ps response.She said: Sorry. Ill have a word with Gran... again.Moonpig was originally founded in 2000 but was bought by online photo printing company in 2011 for £120million.

title: tattoo addict walking advert brand logos facebook pepsi monster
story: Scott Lincoln, 46, insists he has absolutely ‘no regrets’ after getting his entire body inked with 68 tatts - including 20 logos of his favourite drinks, movies and games.The dad-of-eight from Hobart, Tasmania, Australia, claims to be proud of his vast collection of popular culture tatts, with the retired firefighter revealing they were a way to pay homage to some of his favourite things in le.And his devoted we Elisabete, 43, was so inspired by her husband’s tattoos that she also decided to get the logo of her favourite supermarket Woolworths inked on her hand - hitting the headlines earlier this month for the bizarre stunt.Scott said: “I used to be really afraid of getting tattoos because I thought they would hurt.“But like everyone always says, once you get one you just want more. They’re really addictive.“I have 68 tattoos in total, and lots of them are logos of my favourite drinks, movies, and games.“My we tells me I’m like a walking advertisement. I always laugh about it, we think it’s great.“She recently got a Woolworths tattoo as well to show her devotion to the brand.“I always used to drink a lot of Pepsi, as well as other energy drinks like V, Monster and Mother. So I decided to get their logos inked on my skin.“If any new drinks come out that I really like, I get them tattooed on me.“It’s the same with movies and games. I get the ones I really love inked on me.“A lot of my movie tattoos are from films that my kids love, so they get really happy when they see it on my skin.“That was a big reason why I have so many movie tattoos. I got them for my kids.“I think it will be great to look back on them when I’m older and have all those great memories.”Scott and Elisabete have both insisted that other people’s opinions of their tattoos don’t phase them – and the pair have said that they will continue to get inked in the future.Scott said: “I don’t worry about what other people think. I get these tattoos because I like them, and they look cool.“At the end of the day, it’s my body and other people’s opinions don’t matter.“We’re not the types to take ourselves too seriously. We just really love tattoos and enjoy getting inked.“I’m really proud of them and wouldn’t change a thing.”

title: holidaymakers share shocking photos of battered and broken suitcases after manchester airport handlers caught hurling bags onto trailer
story: Footage emerged of a careless worker throwing suitcases so hard they smashed onto the tarmac.He was captured by shocked traveller Elizabeth Evans, after a Ryanair flight landed from Malaga last week.Now passengers have now been posting images of their broken baggage following ious flights this month.It isnt clear  the bags were damaged during their journeys to and from Manchester Airport or  it was careless Swissport workers.Craig Coop, 55, and his we Susan, 34, arrived at Manchester from watching the Grand Prix in Singapore to find their bags crushed.He said: We were appalled to see our suitcases coming down the conveyor crushed. These are £200 bags. It takes some force to break the wheels and crush them like that.The contractor for a flight simulator firm claims his iPad screen was cracked so he lodged a Swissports customer service desk.He said: They said it wasnt damaged enough for them to do anything and wed have to contact Etihad.We were trying to explain how dficult the wheels would make our train journey. They just didnt care.Michelle Knight also shared pictures of her broken bag after travelling to Almeria, Spain, from Manchester Airport.And Hannah Henry, 21, from Stockport, flew back from Palma in Spain on June 26 to find her bag was destroyed.She said: I noticed straight away when it came off the conveyor. There was a big crack down one side.Hannah has now had to fight through Tui to get her bag replaced - and she said she had to settle for a lesser version of the original.A Swissport spokesman said: “We take our baggage handling responsibilities very seriously and we handle all complaints on a case by case basis.”It comes after Elizabeth posted the shocking footage online when she noticed her own case slide off the trailer and onto the floor with the force it is thrown.She can be heard saying thats mine yeah, as her pink suitcase topples to the ground - while the workers colleague looks on.The 28-year-old, from Bury, told the Manchester Evening News: Im very angry and shocked. It was a new case. The case is dented and the protective layer has been torn off it.The Swissport worker can be seen chucking bags onto the trailer without looking, and only stops to scoop up the fallen cases after five had hit the ground.A Manchester Airport spokeswoman said: “We are disappointed to see this unacceptable handling of bags by a Swissport employee and have raised this with them directly.”Meanwhile, a £1,000 guitar case made from the same material as a Boeing 787 was destroyed by easyJet baggage handlers.John Challis posted footage of him picking up the indestructible carbon fibre case in Berlin to discover it had gouges and cracks in it.EasyJet have apologised for the incident and say they are looking into the issue.

title: family visit one thousand wetherspoons ten year pub crawl
story: The Latchfords have spent 10 years touring Britain and Ireland and were first through the door at the chains latest opening in Somerset last week.They ticked off 900 in the first six years but were so prolic they have since had to wait for new ones to open.The only existing bars they havent been to yet are the two beyond security at Heathrows Terminal 5 - which they plan to attend the next time they go on holiday.Their odyssey began with a throwaway promise that mum Sheila, 61, made to son Christy, then 17, which, due to his autism, he took literally and held them to.Sheila, of Kidderminster, said: Our daughter Amy works at the Penny and Black Wetherspoon in Kidderminster and when she started Christy was not yet 18.We wanted to take him in to show her working behind the bar but in those days they had a really strict rule which meant anyone under 18 had to have a meal.We had just eaten so left. I said rather foolishly, or fortunately depending on how you look at it, dont worry, when you are 18 we will go to all of them.When you say something like that to someone with autism it is taken seriously. The minute he turned 18 he was back in the Penny and Black in Kidderminster.We were never intending to do them all, but had promised him and he wouldnt let us forget it.It didnt occur to us it could be doable until I had to go to Scotland to work. They drove me up and we went to ones in Dundee and Edinburgh and it just went from there.The chain currently has around 900 pubs open across the UK but some of the ones the Latchford family have previously visited have since closed.Sheila, husband Keith, 63, and Christy took six years to do the first 900 but in the last four years they have had to wait for new ones to open.The family did all the local area ones first around the Midlands which they could get to in a day and back, before focusing on big cities such as Manchester, Liverpool, Bristol and London whilst also enjoying some sightseeing.They have been to every corner of the UK and to Ireland three times to do all the Wetherspoon pubs in both Northern and Southern Ireland.Sheila, a part-time civil servant, added: It was a lot easier when there were loads to do, we could just fly up to Glasgow and walk around and come straight back.We would often book the night away, next week we are going to the new one in St Pancreas when it opens.We only target openings now and keep a close eye on the website and are part of the Wetherspoon appreciation society group on Facebook.The only ones we have not been to are the ones in Heathrow terminal 5 which are after security. We will have to do that when we plan our next holiday.But as far as we know we have done every other one in the UK and Southern Ireland.The family reached the 1,000 milestone when they were first through the door at the opening of the Palladium Electric in Midsomer Norton, Somerset, last week.The latest one in Midsomer Norton was our 1,000th, Sheila said. They dont serve Champagne anymore but we had a nice bottle of sparkling wine instead.It was a real landmark but unfortunately we were only there for a limited time but had a good look around.Sheila says their orders y from coffees to pints and on around half the 1,000 occasions they have added either a breakfast or evening meal to their visit.She added: We really like them and always make a beeline for them even  they are ones we have been to before.The prices are very reasonable but we also love the surroundings. They refurbish a lot of old buildings and there are lots of converted churches, banks, theatres etc.Probably the old Caley picture house in Edinburgh is our favourite but there are so many really good ones.We also all really like the Cabot Court hotel in Weston-super-Mare which is right on the seafront.Keith, a full time carer for Christy, now 28, said: Everyone tends to say that the historical buildings are the best, and that is true.There are some beautul conversions of old premises and some of the newer pubs in particular are fantastic.It is a great hobby for us together and Christy loves it.Wetherspoon founder and chairman Tim Martin congratulated the family on their achievement.He said: “This is a wonderful achievement by Sheila, Keith and Christy.“They must have travelled tens of thousands of miles over the years to visit each Wetherspoon pub.“We thoroughly appreciate their loyalty and commitment and trust they will continue to visit our pubs for many more years to come.”

title: chancellor announces early budget
story: The Treasury announced the date yesterday - just days after denying to The Sun that it would be brought forward to avoid a Parliamentary log jam.It means critical decisions over tax and spending will be presented to MPs before any Brexit deal is agreed with Brussels.Ardent Eurosceptics have claimed some in their ranks could vote down parts of the Budget in protest at any further concessions to the EU. It marks the first time a Budget or Autumn Statement has been held on Monday since the height of the credit crisis ten years ago.In November 2008, then Chancellor Alistair Darling said Labour announced a borrowing binge to try and kick-start the economy and lt it out of recession.Taking to Twitter yesterday, Philip Hammond said: “I’ll set out how our balanced approach is getting debt falling while supporting our vital public services, and how we are building a stronger, more prosperous economy.”Government insiders yesterday admitted the earlier date meant “big economic decisions” were unlikely. But the Chancellor is under pressure to relieve the strain on strivers while finding money for the NHS and the police.Theresa May earlier this month admitted tax hikes were inevitably going to be required to help pay for a £20 billion NHS windfall.But experts last week said borrowing had come down at such a rate no new hikes may be needed this year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: And some of them chanting the slogan “from the river to the sea” favoured by Hamas and the PLO, who demand the liquidation of Israel.Lovely people.That will have put to rest any worries the British Jewish community might have, no? title: phone deals public over paying
story: Ofcom is concerned that 1.5 million on bundled deals continue to pay the original price after the minimum contract period ends.Providers do not tell them they have paid off the handset, and need to pay only for calls, texts and data.Ofcom yesterday said it was “unacceptable” that providers were not open about the costs of each part of the package.It is now consulting on ­making firms break down the cost of each.It will also look at what extra information should be given to customers.Providers could be forced to automatically move customers to a cheaper SIM-only plan once they reach the minimum term of any contract which includes a handset.Or they may have to reduce the monthly cost to reflect that the handset element has been paid off.The charity said EE, Three and Vodafone routinely continued to charge customers for handsets after they had paid them off in full. Gillian Guy, of Citizens Advice, said: “This move could make a real dference.“While greater transparency around pricing would be a step in the right direction, what ­people really want is not to be charged for products they already own.”Ofcom is seeking comments on the proposals by November 7.GOT a story?
